title: Union Mills, Burnham Overy
text:
Union Mills or Roy's Mills are a <a href="Listed%20building">Grade II listed</a> combined <a href="tower%20mill">tower mill</a> and <a href="watermill">watermill</a> at <a href="Burnham%20Overy">Burnham Overy</a>, <a href="Norfolk">Norfolk</a>, <a href="England">England</a> which has been converted to residential accommodation.
History.
The watermill was built in 1737, this date being recorded on the watermill. As originally built, it was a two-storey mill. Thomas Beeston was the miller in 1802. The windmill was built in 1814 and bears a tablet inscribed "T. B. 1814 PEACE", referring to the banishment of <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> to <a href="Elba">Elba</a> in that year. The watermill was probably raised by a storey at this date. The mills were offered for sale by <a href="auction">auction</a> at the Norfolk Hotel, <a href="Norwich">Norwich</a> on 3 August 1825. The windmill was described as having five floors and the Patent sails had shutters made of <a href="copper">copper</a>. The mills were not sold. James Read took them, and worked them until his death in 1864. William Love Porritt, the son-in-law of James Read then took the mills. The mills were offered for sale by auction at the Hoste Arms Inn, <a href="Burnham%20Market">Burnham Market</a> on 13 July 1870. They were then being let to Porritt at an annual rental of £225. In 1893, the windmill was dismantled and the watermill fitted out with roller milling machinery.
In 1896, the mills had a steam engine as auxiliary power. This had been replaced by a gas engine by 1925. In May 1935, the mill tower was burnt out in a fire. The tower was refitted, and the former conical roof replaced with two cowled ventilators. An oil engine was the auxiliary power source in 1937. On <a href="North%20Sea%20flood%20of%201953">1 February 1953</a>, the mills were flooded to a depth of . The mills were still in use at this time but had ceased working by 1969. In 1999 the mills were purchased for conversion. A new <a href="ogee%20cap">ogee cap</a> was constructed and fitted to the windmill tower.
Description.
The windmill is a six-storey tower mill with an ogee cap which has a gallery. There is a stage at third-floor level. The mill had four double Patent sails carried on a cast-iron windshaft. The windmill drove two pairs of <a href="Millstones%23Types">French Burr millstones</a>, and was also capable of driving the three pairs of French Burr millstones in the watermill.
The watermill is a three-storey brick building with a roof of <a href="pantile">pantile</a>s. It is powered by an undershot <a href="Jean-Victor%20Poncelet">Poncelet</a> waterwheel made by Whitmore & Binyon, the <a href="Wickham%20Market">Wickham Market</a>, <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>, <a href="millwright">millwright</a>s. The watermill drove three pairs of French Burr millstones and was also capable of driving the two pairs of French Burr millstones in the windmill.
